newsitem.title: UK: GOLF-DALY PULLS OUT OF OPEN DUE TO PERSONAL PROBLEMS.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-DALY PULLS OUT OF OPEN DUE TO PERSONAL PROBLEMS.

text.p: John Daly, the 1995 British Open champion, has withdrawn from this year's event saying he needs to look after his "personal health and well-being", organisers said on Wednesday.
Daly has been having treatment after returning to his former alcoholic habits and his withdrawal from next week's open at Royal Troon was not unexpected.
The American sent a letter to Michael Bonallack, secretary of the Royal and Ancient Club which runs the Open, confirming his withdrawal.

He had not played since he pulled out after nine holes of his second round in last month's U.S. Open at the Congressional Club near Washington and there was a question mark then over whether he would play at Troon.
He said then he was suffering from "physical and mental fatigue".
His letter to Bonallack said he was "saddened and discouraged not to be in the British Open this year. But my personal health and well-being require me to be elsewhere.
"I look forward to returning to the British Open next year," Daly added in the letter.
Daly burst into prominence when he won the U.S. PGA title in 1991 after being the ninth alternate in the field and without a practice round on the Crooked Stick course.
It became apparent later that he had an alcohol problem.
He managed to give up drinking and in 1995 won the British Open at St Andrews in a playoff with Italian Costantino Rocca.

Daly had two months of rehabilitation in the Betty Ford Clinic before he signed a new contract with the Callaway Golf Company in May with the condition that he continue to participate in a structured care programme to deal with his alcoholism.
He returned to the Tour two weeks before the U.S. Open and made the cut both times.

But after pulling out at Congressional, he said: "Even though I thought I was going to be strong enough to come right back and play three straight weeks on tour, I found out I was wrong. I just started feeling real weak after a few holes today and by the time I got to number nine I was physically exhausted."
He said then that he would take several weeks off and would embark on an intensive fitness programme, working with a nutritional specialist and a physical fitness expert.
